To be honest, you can build solid replacements for simple processes like Expense Reimbursments, Leave Requests, or anything that may have involved email Word documents or PDFs around. First off let me state that as soon as this message will post, you will see a post by Marketing giving it 5 stars to take away the meaning in this post.

K2 Upper Management - This is the land of misfit managers. People come to K2 so they can get a title and no nothing to provide success for K2. This company gives out Director titles like it's free bottle water. At any other company these people have nothing they bring to the table. All they can think of is bring expensive trainers to train lower staff to have them do their jobs better (Which is no the issues. its K2's lack of leadership). For once I would love to see them take a Leadership for Dummies course. Most of the company sits around and plan on how long until the next Leadership person hits the door or is fired. Trust me it's talked about a lot!!!!

The new CEO seems like a good guy and is trying to drive the boat, but the boat has a massive hole and is taking on water fast. Not sure how long until he taps out and moves on.

In all the years I have been there this is the worse it has been. No Leads, Marketing is out for their KPI's and not Sales. Product marketing, who tells company where and how to sell, and do not listen to the guys fighting the battles. Middle management are just report jockeys and just take off office space.

No career development at all. If you are not brought in as a Director, then there is no chance you will move up or side ways in the organization. The team I am on, no one has ever been promoted in the all the time I have been there. People leave but not promoted.

Would I recommend K2? If you care about the company you work at and want to make a difference then K2 is not the spot for you. Its High Tech Chop Shop. No passion, no drive, and this blotch on your resume will only make you suffer.
advice_to_mgmt: Not sure if it is too late for anything to be fixed. Again the CEO is trying but if he looks and see the people below him and what they do each day then he would see where the problems are. Listen to your people, they will tell you the truth, but not listening and assuming you know what is best without the feedback is just being CRAZY.

review_title: Lack of vision and lack of communication
years_at_company: Lack of vision and lack of communication

good benefits
friendly colleagues

cons:
Lack of leadership - there are too many people trying to steer the ship, there is a lack of support from all levels of leadership to developing employees. Low morale, high turnover.

Lack of communication - because everyone is trying to lead, communication is difficult to manage. People never seem to know what is going on, and if they do, it changes a few minutes later.

No reviews/feedback - there's no growth here. You come in at what you will leave at, unless you become a golden child, but you'll never know how you are doing.

Employee tenure falls in two buckets - either you've been there from the beginning or you last a year.

The culture is driven by competition, and all gatherings are built upon this. Who can drink the most? Who is the fastest. Who can get the most money. No team building exercises, and no cross departmental gatherings fostering company unity. After a year, I still only knew the people I sat next to daily.

Lack of trust of the employees - constant micromanaging and a feeling of 'not fast enough' in your daily life leads to burn out pretty quickly.

Location is also an issue. No nearby food joints to walk to. You need a car to work here.
advice_to_mgmt: Figure out your path or you risk alienating really talented people before they have a chance to do great things for you.

Relaxed environment , relatively flexible working and some of the best people you’d hope to meet and work with, around the world
cons:
We’ve been through a massive amount of change in the past couple of years and in particular the past six months - some good, some bad but for many of us this has been a major upheaval.

Senior management is being rebuilt and needs to cement itself fast as general feeling around the company is not positive and we are losing great people to competitors around the globe.

Communication has been generally poor over the years but seems to be improving under the new CEO.
advice_to_mgmt:
Make the people feel like they count and are not just numbers - there are a huge amount of people in this business who have put in many years and they need to feel appreciated again.

Make the staff feel invested in the company and roll out an appropriate stock option plan to do this - people want to stay but generally don’t feel like they have the ability to build something for themselves.

Improve benefits , particularly pension - this is very poor in the EMEA region and lags way behind the market and competitors.

Evan is doing a great job thus far and has made some big decisions - let’s hope the hiring of the next exec round is the real deal.
